review_title: Everything you hear about HCA is true.
pros: I loved my patients and coworkers.
cons: Management is unsupportive. There are hardly any policies for anything and if there are, employees do not follow them. The staffing crisis (especially in the ED) is dangerous, and management is unwilling to roll up their sleeves and help. They cannot retain staff because they aren’t competitive with wages. The work environment is toxic and management doesn’t seem to care or do anything to fix it. When I asked for the opportunity to be educated in another specialty to further my career, I was denied. I was constantly put in situations that put my license and patients at risk. I will literally never work here again.

pros: I love my team and my manager but that only goes so far and doesn’t help me pay my bills.
cons: The pay at HCA is ridiculous. They are the only hospital in the area who did not give a raise to accommodate cost of living. They gave us $2 to try and make us feel better. As a new nurse, when you finish training they tell you that you’ll get a raise, but what they don’t tell you is that the raise is 0.60 cents. Then at the 6 month review we got .80 cents and then the whole hospital got $2. There are new grad nurses who haven’t even finished training who now got their hourly instead of a stipend and got the $2 raise and are making a dollar less than nurses who have been there three years.

job_title: Diagnostic Imaging Supervisor in Dallas, TX
pros: Some of the people that work there are actually nice and do their jobs
cons: I was hired on as the diagnostic imaging supervisor for 2nd shift. The onboarding process is terrible and I ended up starting well after the expected start date, there is literally zero training. No one shows you anything or even discusses what is expected. No one introduced me to my team they just threw me in there and expected me to figure it out with a bunch of techs who all felt like they were the supervisor. Management and higher ups do nothing about people who are disrespectful or do not want to work. On top of that the communication is terrible and no one ever actually talks to you. You are a robot to them work hard and fast and never slow down and do not communicate an issue with them because even with text documentation that they knew the situation and approved tardy or absences they will still fire you for attendance.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Dallas, TX
pros:
Fair Pay
Easier to get a job there as ADN nurse 
Relocation and bonus pay is generous
Great benefits
Tuition reimbursement 
Great staff
Night house supervisor genuinely cares
Physicians are for the most part kind and familiar so we know what their expectations are.
cons:
Upper management  not receptive to suggestions on improvement of unit.
Getting supplies to do our job can be difficult some days and makes it hard to do our job
Managers do NOT fill in like they are supposed to when we are short staffed 
We have great days then we have TERRIBLE days, sometimes terrible weeks related to staffing.
Floating to Med Surg floors in South Tower is the worst. The entire tower should be condemned. It’s depressing, dirty, and consistently short staffed. 
Management makes it hard to transfer if you are unhappy

review_title: Medical City Dallas Hospital is one of the best employers for growth and advancement...
pros: The growth and advancement opportunities are  tremendous. As a member of the management team, there is a great deal of support, continuing education, and demonstration of appreciation. Pay, raises and bonuses are good also. Hard work is greatly rewarded. Training and education plans are the norm for MCDH.
cons: Highly stressful and very competitive to get on and stay on the management team. Performance and accountability are overlooked and covered up to protect managers. Subordinates are often scapegoats for management failures.  Not an easy place to work, but profitable and rewarding when successful. Many times meetings are required after-hours and outside of regular work hours. As a hospital, on-call situations may be required. Flexible schedules are required.

review_title: A company that allowed bedside nurses to achieve work/life balance
pros:
Work/life balance
Self-scheduling
Generous Paid Time Off (PTO) with longevity
Car
cons: Bedside nursing has become too stressful, busy and difficult with more and more demands placed on the nurses including extreme complexity of care, so many healthcare and government mandates to follow now and the patient satisfaction demands that are beat into you and over the top. No career ladder direction and support. Didn't feel valued the last few years at the company. No

pros: I liked my fellow rn colleagues and charge nurse. Covered parking was nice to have. Employee events were fun to go to. CEO seemed like a good guy- very personable and a good motivational speaker.
cons: No techs, understaffed every shift it seems. Manager unbelievably out of touch with employee needs. I didn't like being forced to sit in unit staff meetings for 90 minutes after working a night shift. Also, charge nurse always had patients as well. Many times I had no help from charge bc she was always busy with her patients.

job_title: Emergency Room RN in Farmers Branch, TX
pros: When I first joined I felt good about management. I felt like they supported staff.
cons: Everyone started leaving and it raised red flags. Everything began to deteriorate. A large mandatory staff meeting was held with the COO. It felt pointless, nothing changed. Still losing staff weekly. Now we have little to no lunch breaks. Somedays I'm so busy I don't get a bathroom break. For example, you receive 2-3 untriaged patients at once and it makes you feel concerned for keeping your RN license. Everyone is struggling to stay above water. Staff does not feel supported by management.

pros: The benefits were good as far as stock options.
cons: Where do I start. They are a for profit hospital that treats their employees like robots.  They are extremely cheap.  One time we had zero c collars in the ER after implementing a ridiculous for profit Trauma protocol. The hospital only cares about profile much like a tech company. The management is in and out in a 6 month rotation. Nobody stays & everyone talks crap about one another behind their co workers back. Toxic environment.

pros: I enjoy helping people and making sure that everything was in top-notch shape for our customers which is our patients
cons: Had to see a lot of tragedy but is something you  you just have to deal with in the hospital situation.  I'm always in constant prayer for the patients.

pros: The benefits are okay.  HR are the only people that do their jobs, management doesn't care.
cons: I worked for two different clinics with HCA, one at the  Dallas Medical City Hospital and the other at the Medial City in Plano. Both were terrible working experiences. I would never recommended going to work at an HCA owned hospital or clinic in Dallas or even going there. So many employees violate HIPAA, very unstable work environment and a lot of drama and stress over petty stuff. I hated the 6 months I worked with HCA. It was miserable. Both clinics I worked for the Office Managers quit, so any people were quitting when I was working there that I, myself found a new job with another clinic and got out of there fast.

review_title: Not a good place to work
pros: Strong relationships between staff at peer levels
cons:
Pay is not competitive for market, as a result staffing is insufficient.  
Benefits have been slashed dramatically over the past few years
Patient care is secondary to fiscal performance
Minimal opportunities for growth, not a place to develop a career
No loyalty to employees, staff with long careers (25-30+ yrs) fired on the spot.
STRONG history of nepotism!!

review_title: Entirely focused on profit to the detriment of staff and patients
pros: The location is good, co-workers are usually good, and parking is free.
cons: Upper management & immediate management are far too concerned with HCAPS and profit. Managers that care about their staff and safe staffing levels are not in the upper management clique and are weeded out quickly. New management hires ALWAYS brown nose the higher ups.

review_title: Not a good place to work
pros: The employees are dedicated and friendly for the most part.  the benefits started out good but went down hill rapidly
cons: For the most part my time there was good until about 3 years before I left. During this time the work environment became so stressful it affected my health.

review_title: It used to be a good place to work...
pros: I had a lot of friends there.
cons:
Pay is below market for my years of experience; they short-staff, and then ride you to clock out on time- it has become ridiculous. They continue to pile more work on as if the hour is lengthening, but give paltry, if any, raises now.
Upper management is totally out of touch with the reality of the job. Their solution to problems is form a committee, to come up with a new form to fill out, to make sure the last form they made was filled out. Its ridiculous.

pros: Gave my great experience right out of graduation from nursing school. It helped me get my feet in the water and they really trained me for ICU.
cons: There aren't really any downsides. There aren't really any downsides. There aren't really any downsides  There aren't really any downsides

review_title: Spent entire career there but many people looking to elsewhere, lowest paying hospital.

cons: Horrible mgmt from supervisors up to COOs.  Unethical in their treatment of employees.  Top heavy in mgmt.  Pay is nowhere close to competitive.
